description: Dive into "Castles of Newcastle: A Journey Through Time" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Castles of Newcastle: A Journey Through Time

sources.snippet: Newcastle keep or Newcastle Castle is possibly a bit overlooked as a tourist spot, competing with the Quayside and numerous galleries and museums. However, it's an interesting place to visit and was recently revamped along with the nearby Black Gate in 2015.
sources.shortName: Newcastle Keep in Newcastle City Centre

places.name: Newcastle Keep

reviews.text:
Superb castle keep in excellent condition.
LOTS OF STEPS !
But soooo worth it for the amazing views from the roof !! Part of Newcastle Castle.
The keep was built between 1168 and 1178, and the current roof and battlements were added around 1811. The castle site has been used for defense since Roman times. It historical place

It was a spur of the moment decision to go visit the Newcastle keep on a gloriously Sunny Sunday afternoon in October.  It was quite quiet, with a few people visiting at the same time. (Glad it was quiet I like it that way).  It was better than I expected. My only negative would be the weeds right at the top of the castle.  That aside, it was a great day for pictures of the Quayside skyline with the bridges and cathedral with St James park in the distance.

Newcastle council also could maybe clear the street (to the left as you look at the entrance of the Keep).

places.address: The Castle, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 1RQ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Newcastle Castle, a stone fortress and former prison, was built between 1168 and 1178. Situated on the site of a Roman fortress, it offers stunning views over the city and river. The castle includes the Castle Keep and the Black Gate, both over 800 years old. Throughout its history, it has served as a fort, prison, Sheriffs office, and air raid shelter.

sources.snippet: Discover the ancient history of the city by visiting Newcastle Castle – the Norman keep, and the Black Gate offer interesting exhibits, and the 360-degree commanding views from the keep’s rooftop are the best in town. Looking down on the bustling streets of Newcastle, you’d never know that deep underground lies Victoria Tunnel, an extraordinary coal-wagon thoroughfare built between 1839 and 1842 and used as an air-raid shelter during WWII.

It is uncertain whether the Roman bridge at  Monkchester survived into Norman times but it is likely that, at the very least, the foundations remained. In Anglo-Saxon times the fort was reused as a cemetery and an Anglo-Saxon church was built. Like the Romans, the Normans recognised the strategic importance of this bridging point.
sources.shortName: Newcastle History Castle and Town Walls

sources.snippet: Newcastle Castle in Newcastle upon Tyne is a partially restored Norman fortification and one of the best preserved of its kind in Britain. As the ‘castle’ that gave Newcastle its name, it has seen over 800 years of history and today provides an exciting walk through Britain’s medieval past.

Newcastle Castle is a must-visit attraction in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne which not only explores the rich history of the city but also offers incredible views from its rooftop. There is much to discover about Newcastle Castle, from which the city gained its name many centuries ago.
sources.shortName: Newcastle Castle - Attraction in Newcastle upon…

sources.snippet: Newcastle keep or Newcastle Castle is possibly a bit overlooked as a tourist spot, competing with the Quayside and numerous galleries and museums. However, it's an interesting place to visit and was recently revamped along with the nearby Black Gate in 2015.
sources.shortName: Newcastle Keep in Newcastle City Centre

sources.snippet: Newcastle Castle, The Castle that gave Newcastle it's name is a medieval Castle in the heart of the city and is a great destination for both visitors to the area and locals alike. We had visited Newcastle Castle a few years ago and it was great to go back.
sources.shortName: Newcastle Castle | What to expect from a visit

places.name: Newcastle Castle

reviews.text: A fascinating experience of an almost fully intact castle with dark narrow stone corridors, winding spiral staircases and grand high ceiling halls. Worth the entry price for the views from the rooftop alone!. A historical gem with friendly and knowledgeable staff and a variety of events too.

The history of this place is very interesting, and presented very well. Especially the pictures of how the area used to look like so many years ago. The staff is friendly too. When you buy a ticket, it's valid for one year, and you get access to both the Castle Keep and the Black Gate (with a small shop).
The view of Newcastle on top of the Castle Keep is amazing. I stayed here for half an hour overlooking the city, including the trains.

Absolutely loved visiting Newcastle Castle! I was genuinely impressed by the stunning architecture and how well this historic site has been preserved. Every stone seems to tell a story, and the views from the top are simply breathtaking - a perfect blend of history and scenery. Walking through the narrow passages and ancient chambers truly felt like stepping back in time. A must-visit for anyone interested in medieval history or simply looking to explore one of Newcastle's architectural gems.

places.address: The Black Gate, Castle Garth, Newcastle upon Tyne NE1 1RQ, United Kingdom
